awd_titl_txt: Neuroendocrine Mechanisms Regulating Adolescent Social Development
awd_abstract_narration:
Adolescence is a time of remarkable development in social, emotional, and cognitive abilities. However, it is also a time of increased vulnerability to mental health disorders and increased sensation seeking thought to underlie an elevated incidence of deaths and injuries from accidents. These behavioral changes are accompanied by complex interactions between hormones and the brain, and a major challenge is to parse out which neural and hormonal factors are responsible for adolescent behavioral changes and which merely coincide with them. Activation of pubertal hormones in adolescence is the primary candidate. In this research project, a new model is introduced that makes use of a seasonally-breeding hamster species, for which the timing of puberty can be controlled simply by manipulating day length -- hamsters born and raised in long, summer-like day lengths undergo puberty early, whereas those born in short, winter-like day lengths delay puberty by several months in order to prevent breeding during the harsh winter months. The proposed experiments use this model to test the role of pubertal hormones in adolescent social behavioral and neural development. This research will advance understanding of the neural and hormonal factors that both drive adolescent social development and underlie the increased vulnerability of this life stage. An additional part of this project is the principal investigator's oversight of a student-run outreach program with the Buffalo Zoo to create zoo camps designed to spark children's interest in the sciences. The inclusion of University student participation promotes and provides training in science outreach and early childhood science education. 

This project tests the role of pubertal hormones in adolescent behavioral and neural development, focusing on play behavior, the predominant social behavior in adolescent animals, and the 'social' vasopressin (VP) pathway, a pathway recently implicated in adolescent social development. The goal of Aim 1 is to determine the role of pubertal hormones in the development of the 'social' VP pathway.  Its neuroanatomical development in the hamster model is being uncovered using immunohistochemistry and in situ hybridization. Aim 2 serves to determine the projections through which the 'social' VP pathway regulates play. The role of four key projection areas is being tested with site-specific infusions of a VP agonist and antagonist to determine how this pathway regulates social development. Aim 3 involves an initial test of the role of estradiol in early adolescent behavior. Estradiol levels are measured using enzyme immunoassay in the hamster model to determine whether day length impacts circulating estradiol levels in juvenile hamsters. This research program will begin to map puberty-dependent and puberty-independent neural circuits and specify how they interact to regulate adolescent social development.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Adolescence is a time of remarkable change. Alongside pubertal development, adolescents acquire the social, emotional, and cognitive skills that are necessary for independence. Many of these changes are thought to be driven by the increase in gonadal hormones at puberty (puberty-dependent), whereas others can occur independently of puberty (puberty-independent). This distinction is important for understanding the mechanisms that drive social, emotional, and cognitive development of adolescence, but also for uncovering potential contributors to the increase in neuropsychiatric and behavioral disorders that arise during this formative period. Recent evidence also suggests that gonadal hormones can impact social development during the juvenile period, prior to the onset of adolescence. This grant investigated the role of gonadal hormones in neural and behavioral social development.

Experiments in this grant dissected out puberty-dependent and puberty-independent actions on adolescent neural and behavioral development. Specifically, it was found that puberty-dependent mechanisms impact the development of vasopressin and dopamine pathways known to affect social and affective behaviors. The development of vasopressin pathways implicated in stress and autonomic regulation, however, occurred independently of pubertal hormones. In contrast, adolescent behavioral development was not strictly puberty-dependent or puberty-independent, but rather a mix of the two, i.e., individual behavioral changes during adolescence are simultaneously impacted by puberty-dependent and puberty-independent mechanisms. These findings indicate that adolescent behavioral development is regulated by the combined actions of puberty-dependent and puberty-independent neural pathways. The impact of disruptions to vasopressin on adolescent social development was also tested. Findings raised the hypothesis that vasopressin regulates juvenile and adolescent social behaviors through its actions on arousal. Finally, experiments demonstrated that gonadal hormones influence social and affective behaviors of juveniles as well as brain areas that regulate these behaviors. These findings demonstrate that the role of gonadal hormones begins earlier than previously appreciated and argues against the current zeitgeist that the gonads are quiescent during the juvenile phase, prior to puberty.

The broader impacts of the grant provided educational and research opportunities for high-school, undergraduate, and graduate students, including those from underrepresented and underprivileged backgrounds. The principal investigator (PI) organized an online seminar titled, Play in Zoology, for high school students in the Life Sciences Career Program at the Buffalo Zoo. The PI also participated in several programs that provide research opportunities for undergraduate students from underprivileged and underrepresented backgrounds.
